title: Richard J. Telford
text: Richard Telford is a Associate Professor in Plant Ecology in the Department of Biological Sciences, University of Bergen. His main research interests are in quantitative palaeoecology, and in open and reproducible science. He teaches biostatistics using R.

About
This website was made with quarto and hosted on GitHub pages.
The quarto source files that make this website can be found in the GitHub repo. Perhaps they will help you make your website.

Funded positions
Any funded positions will be advertised on Jobbnorge, on the EECRG webpage and on twitter etc.

Visitors
Visitors are welcome for a research visit.

Interns
Some projects have paid internship positions, often for fieldwork during the summer.

Project ideas
If you have ideas for a project and you think I would be a useful partner or supervisor, email me (richard.telford@uib.no) to have a chat.

Doctoral level courses

Forthcoming
Living Norway Open Science Training “Research Course on Open, Reproducible and Transparent Science in Ecology”, Hjerkinn, Norway 13–18 November 2023


Recent

Living Norway Open Science Training “Open, Reproducible, and Transparent Science in Ecology”, team member, Finse, Norway, 2022
R for palaeoecologists, Course Leader, University of Cape Town, 2019
Plant functional traits course, Team member, UNIS, Svalbard, 2018
Plant functional traits course, Team member, Chengdu, China, 2015

Master level courses

University of Bergen
I am the course leader for three 5 ECTS Master’s level courses.

Bio300B – Biostatistics
Bio302 – Biological data analysis II

Bio303 – Ordination and gradient analysis

I also make contributions to

Bio250 – Palaeoecology. I teach the section on dating and age depth models.

Rklubben
I host a weekly peer-learning drop-in session for R code (and statistical) problems (Fridays 1400-1600 in Tunet).

Teaching resources

Together with Dr Aud Halbritter, Dr Jonathan Soulé and others, I wrote Enough R to write a thesis. This is a collection of interactive workbooks and shiny apps to teach the use of R, quarto for reproducible documents, git and GitHub for version control, and R package development.
These workbooks are used to support regular and special courses.

Ongoing Research

Durin
The NFR-funded Durin explores the under-appreciated roles of dwarf-shrubs in responding to and influencing global climate change.
Role: Partner


ExperTS
ExperTS is the latest of several projects funding training in trait-based ecology.
Role: Partner

Past projects

PalaeoDrivers
PalaeoDrivers was an NFR funded project to develop methods to test the significance of quantitative palaeoenvironmental reconstructions.
Role: PI


The Matrix
The Matrix was an NFR-funded collaboration with Makerere University, Uganda, to explore biodiversity in the fragmented tropical forests and the surrounding agricultural matrix.
Role: Co-PI


FunCaB
FunCab was an NFR funded project to investigate the role of Functional group interactions in mediating climate change impacts on the Carbon dynamics and Biodiversity of alpine ecosystems using the Vestland climate grid.
Role: Partner
